bibl.title: Report on mosquito control work in South Carolina, by [F.M. Boldridge], August 25, 1921

div1.p: [Boldridge's] report on a mosquito survey in South Carolina includes interviews with locals regarding mosquitoes, and information on the incidence of malaria and mosquito control measures.

div1.head: Report on mosquito control work in South Carolina, by [F.M. Boldridge], August 25, 1921
div1.p: AUGUST 25th 1921.

In compliance with telephonic instructions of August 24th-21 from
Mr J. V. Sutton, Chief Claim Agent, Southern Power Company, I pro-
ceeded on the morning of August 25th-21 to Roch Hill, S.C., where
I joined him and proceeded by automobile to Wateree, S.C., The entire
trip was spent in a general conversation concerning the situation
now in question.

When within two miles of the Wateree Power Plant we met Dr. H.R. Carter
and Captain L.M. Fisher, U.S.P.H.S., and after a short conference we
decided to examine the streams crossing the main highway between Wateree
Dam and Colonels Creek.

Careful examination of this stream revealed the fact that there was
more or less breeding of ANOPHELES on both sides of the highway. This
stream seems deep-seated in places and rather shallow in others. Does
not flow freely, but stands in pools. Banks of stream, grassy, and an
abundance of trash, leaves etc, found in each of these pools. Several
pools seemed well stocked with gambusia or top feeding minnows, while
others showed none. BREEDING FREELY.

This stream is narrow and deep seated, containing but little water at
time of examination. Water standing in pools, no running water. Banks
of pools grassy and plenty of leaves, debris etc along banks. Breeding
in this stream was not as large as No. 1, but still breeding freely.
BREEDING FREELY.

This stream was found to be in much better condition than either No. 1,
or No. 2. Water seemed to be flowing freely and stream well stocked
with gambusia or top feeding minnows. We found breeding in a few small
side pools and around some logs in stream. We examined this stream from
the public highway down to the backwaters of the pond. Found some few
breeding the entire distance. BREEDING FREELY.

This stream was not flowing, but standing in pit holes all along the
channel of stream. No gambusia found in any of these pools. Each pool
well filled with leaves and other debris. Each pool examined showed
profuse breeding.
BINDINGS ON STREAM # 5.

This stream seemed to have a good supply of free running water, although
it was pooled on both sides of the culbert which crosses the public
highway. We found a great many gambusia in this stream, and the banks
were fairly clean, however we found some breeding in places.
AUGUST 25th, cont'd.
FINDINGS ON STREAM # 6.

This stream while flowing freely, contained a great amount of leaves
and other debris. We found stream breeding freely all along banks, and
around debris in center of same. Found a great many gambusia or top
feeding minnows in this stream, which probably accounts for same not
breeding profusly, as this is an ideal breeding place.

We secured several specimens from each of the above streams, which
upon hatching prooved to be ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS.

We also examined the house of Ira J. Bush, located on Company property
about 150 yds from backwater of Colonels creek. Caught 9 adult ANOPHELES
QUADRIMACULATUS in this house. The indications are that these mosquitoes
came from the pond, although an examination of the pond at this point
at a later date did not reveal breeding.
AUGUST 30th-21.

This inspection of the Wateree pond was made August 30th-21. The pond
was examined from the Wateree Power Plant up to and including Colonels
Creek. At time of inspection no ANOPHELES were found to be breeding
in the main body of water. We found that the main body of pond was
fairly clear of logs and other debris. Crews of laborers were at work
clearing up and burning logs and debris along banks.

We examined several inlets along main body and found no breeding. The
wave action was found to be good all over the entire pond and extended
well up in each bite or cove. The pond was low at time of inspection,
and the elevations constantly changing.

It was reported that the weather has been unusually dry this season,
and just how that would affect the production of ANOPHELES in the
locality under consideration has not yet been determined, however I
believe it would tend to lessen breeding.

The people living near the pond all report that mosquitoes were much
more numerous during 1919 than than 1920, and a great many state that
there were only a few mosquitoes until the pond was closed.

It should be mentioned, as I believe it is important, that each bite
or cove seemed to be alive with gambusia or top feeding minnows, which
probably played a great part in the destruction of ANOPHELES if there
were any.

To what extent the pond produced ANOPHELES in the early summer and spring
I am unable to say, but I can say that the pond was not producing
ANOPHELES at time this inspection was made.

PROPERTY
OF
GLENN W RAGSDALE.
AUGUST 26th-21.

On Friday, Aug 26th 1921 we examined the property of Glenn W Ragsdale,
which is about four (4) miles from the backwaters of Dutchmans creek.
Caleb Jackson (col) is the tenant living on premises. This property
has two streams on it, one about 400 yards from house and other about
1/4 mile from house.

The stream about 1/4 mile from house was found to have a good supply
of free running water in places, while it was pooled in others. We
found several pools about twenty feet from this stream. These pools
were all breeding profusly. The main stream was found to be breed-
ing profusly in places and freely in others. This stream is filled
with sand beds, and contains a large amount of leaves and other debris.
Stream flows through a large heavily wooded bottom. Stream shows no
signs of ever being affected by the backwaters from the main pond.
Found large cottonwood trees, blauk gum trees, some oak trees and
a great many large willow trees all along area of stream. Found
few gambusia or top feeding minnows in main body of stream. Caught
several adult ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS mosquitoes under the banks of
stream and in old dead log.

Examination of the stream 400 yards from house of Caleb Jackson,
showed free breeding of ANOPHELES. This seems to be a wet weather
stream, and was dried up except in a few pools. A great many half
grown larvae were found in each of these pools, which were ideal
breeding places.

We secured several specimens from each of the above places, which
when hatched out prooved to be ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS.

As far as I am able to judge these two streams are at present in
their natural condition, and show no evidence of ever being affected
by backwater from the main pond.

PROPERTY
OF
GLENN W RAGSDALE.
AUGUST 30th-21.

On August 30th I again visited the Ragsdale place in company with
Captain L.M. Fisher, U.S.P.H.S., and Drs. Hamilton, Dobson and Sanders.
The conditions as shown in my report of August 26th were found to
be exactly the same. Each member of the party was supplied with a
dipper and allowed to dip where they pleased. All were convinced
that this stream was breeding profusly, (that is the stream 1/4 mile
from house) and that the stream about 400 yards from house was
breeding freely.

The party caught about twenty adult ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS under the
banks of the first stream examined.

None of this party seemed to think that the conditions showed any
signs of backwaters of main pond, and in conversation with Dr. Sanders,
who seemed to be familiar with this in locality, he stated that it had
not been cultivated to his knowledge in recent years. (Of course this
refers to the bottom land on stream).

The meadows around this property were allowed to grow up in grass, trees,
and weeds, thus indicating periodically overflow.

PROPERTY
OF
JOHN R. AND J.C. WHITAKER.
AUGUST 27th-21.

On Saturday August 27th-21, Dr. Carter and myself examined the property
of John R. and J.C. Whitaker, which is located about 150 ft. N.E. of
companies public road between Wateree and Great Falls, just above
Miley's creek. The spring is about 250 yards from house. We found
ANOPHELES breeding in the spring and in the spring branch. We also
found ANOPHELES breeding freely in a branch which runs within about
150 yards of house. Both of these branches are somewhat pooled in
places and contain a great many leaves and other debris. John Whitaker
was with us on this examination, and was shown the larvae as we caught
them.

We also examined a barrow pit on the road just above Whitaker's house
but did not find breeding. We recommended at the time to Mr Sutton
that this pit be drained.

We followed the stream from Whitaker's place down to the pond. The
main stream seemed to be fairly swift, and as it neared pond we found
a great many gambusia or top feeding minnows. We examined the pond
at this point but did not find breeding. The wave action was good at
this point of pond. The pond in this area has a great many standing
trees and a great many logs in main body.

At time of examination we found a crew of laborers at work cutting
down and cleaning up this area of pond. The logs and debris collected
by this crew was being burned.

PROPERTY
OF
JOHN R. AND J.C. WHITAKER.
AUGUST 30th-21.

On Tuesday August 30th-21 in company with Captain L.M. Fisher, U.S.P.H.S.,
and Drs. Hamilton, Dobson and Sanders, we went over the entire area of
the Whitaker place. We found the spring and both streams breeding as
stated in report of visit on Aug 27th-21.

We examined the house and found 2 Quadrimaculatus in bedroom. We also
found 2 Quadrimaculatus in stable near house.

We secured a number of larvae from each of these branches and the
spring, which when hatched out proved to be ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS.

We also caught eight adult ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS under the banks of
the branch above spring.

PROPERTY
OF
WILLIAM BELTON.
VISIT # 1.
AUGUST 29th-21.

On August 29th I examined the property of William Belton. The spring
and spring branch is about 100 yards from the house occupied by Wm.
Belton and family. William Belton accompanied us on this trip. He
stated that he had never had mosquitoes until October 1919, and that
there had been plenty of them ever since. He stated that he and his
family had had malaria since June 1920.

Examination of the spring showed that it was breeding ANOPHELES freely,
and that the spring branch was breeding profusly in places and freely
in others. This branch seemed to have a good flow of water, but con-
tained a good deal of rubbish, leaves, etc. There were small pools of
water all along the main spring branch, all of which were breeding
profusly.

We showed the living larvae to Belton, and I talked with him for some
time concerning same. I told him that if he properly cleaned out this
spring and spring branch that he would have no mosquitoes, and I showed
him beyond a shawer of doubt that he was responsible for his family
having malaria. He told me he was going to do as I had directed him.

PROPERTY
OF
WILLIAM BELTON.
VISIT # 2.
AUGUST 30th-21.

On the afternoon of August 30th in company with Captain Fisher and Drs
Hamilton, Dobson and Sanders, we visited the property of William Belton.
We examined the house and out buildings for mosquitoes, but found none.
We next examined the spring branch about 100 yards from house. Here we
found Belton and a farm hand cleaning out spring and spring branch. We
found some full grown larvae in places that they had not reached. The
spring had been well cleaned out and we were not able to find any larvae
in same. Found a good many full grown larvae in some hoof prints below
spring.

This property is about 1 1/8 mile from the backwaters of Colonels creek.
I had previously examined the pond or backwaters below Belton's property.
I found no breeding in pond. Found some few half grown larvae in floatage
of Dead water, these had probably been washed down from above. In the
running water form the branch I found free breeding, and the higher up
I went the more breeding I found.

The dead water contained many gambusia as did the main pond below. The
branch contained much trash and rubish and seemed to be an ideal breed-
ing place for ANOPHELES.

At the point of entrance of this branch to the pond we found a crew of
laborers clearing up and burning all trash, logs and other accumilated debris.

PROPERTY
OF
GEORGE BELTON.
AUGUST 29th-21.
VISIT # 1.

On August 29th I examined the property of George Belton, which is
said to be about 9/10 of a mile from the backwaters of Colonels
Creek. Belton secures his water from a spring about 150 yards from
house. Examination of this spring and spring branch showed both to
be breeding ANOPHELES. The spring and spring branch is on the opposite
side of house from pond. The branch does not flow freely, but stands
in pools, each of which was found to be breeding freely at time of
examination. No gambusia or top feeding minnows were found in this
stream. I would term this area as a whole BREEDING PROFUSLY.

In a conversation with George Belton, whom we found working in a
small blacksmith shop just in front of his house, he told me that
he and his family all had malaria. That malaria had never been in
his family until in October of 1919. That they had always had some
few mosquitoes, but not so many as in the fall of 1919. That the
mosquitoes were not so bad in 1920. That the first case of malaria
in his family developed in November 1919, and whole family has been
down with it at intervals ever since.

PROPERTY
OF
GEORGE BELTON.
VISIT # 2.
AUGUST 30th-21.

On August 30th-21, in company with Captain L.M. Fisher, U.S.P.H.S.,
and Drs. Hamilton, Dobson and Sanders we visited the property of
George Belton.
We examined the spring and spring branch, which is about 150 yards from house on opposite side from pond.

This examination revealed the same facts as shown in report of
visit on the day before.

Several specimens were secured, which when hatched out proved to
be ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS.

Several adult ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS were caught under banks of
stream near spring.

Every member of this inspection party declared that this area
was BREEDING PROFUSLY.
EXAMINATION OF POND NEAR PROPERTY OF GEORGE BELTON.
COLONELS CREEK.
AUGUST 27th-21.

On the afternoon of August 27th-21 I examined the pond at the nearest
point to the property of George Belton. Examined pond for about 1/2 mile?
but found no breeding. Wave action good. Found schools of gambusia or
top feeding minnows in pond and in branches flowing into pond. Examined
the branch which flows from the Belton property. Found no breeding in
same at this point. Current of branch swift, and banks fairly clear
of vegetation.

At time of this examination I found a large crew of laborers cutting
down dead trees in edges of pond and burning same.

PROPERTY
OF
JOE BELL.
VISIT # 1.
AUGUST 29th-21.

On August 29th I examined the property of Joe Bell. The spring and
spring branch is about 100 yards from house. The area of the spring
is very swampy and at time of examination found many small pools of
water along the spring branch, all of which were breeding ANOPHELES
more or less freely. The spring branch was not flowing freely, but
stood in pools, all of which were breeding ANOPHELES freely. This
branch contained a great many leaves and other rubbish and was an
ideal breeding place.

We secured several specimens of larvae, which when hatched out
proved to be ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS.

Caught several adult ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS under the banks around
spring.

I examined this area thoroughly, and followed the spring branch down
stream for about 1/2 mile and found free breeding all along same.
Area BREEDING PROFUSLY.

PROPERTY
OF
JOE BELL.
VISIT # 2.
AUGUST 30th-21.

On August 30th in company with Capt Fisher and Drs Dobson, Hamilton,
and Sanders we visited the property of Joe Bell. We examined the house
and outbuildings for mosquitoes but found none. We found one QUAD-
RIMACULATUS and six PUNCTIPENNIS in buggy top in shed.

Examination of the spring and spring branch showed exactly the condition
stated in Report 1 of Aug 29th-21.

PROPERTY
OF
DAVIDSON ROBERTSON.

On August 29th I visited the property of Davidson Robertson. The house
on this property is located about 200 yards from Penny Fork Branch
and about 200 yards from Cotton House branch. Examination of both of
these branches revealed the fact that they were both breeding ANOPHELES
freely. The Penny Fork branch was breeding profusly in places. It stood
in pools and at time of examination was not flowing freely. A great
deal of trash and leaves was found in nearly all pools. Banks of stream
were grassy, and the area of stream more or less swampy. The Cotton
House branch was flowing freely at time of examination, and did not
seem to be breeding as freely as the Penny Fork branch.

In conversation with Robertson, he told me that there were a great
many mosquitoes in the fall of 1919, but had not had many this year.
He stated that there were a great many mosquitoes in 1908. He stated
that there had always been some malaria in that part of the country,
but that his family had never had it until late in the fall of 1920.

The branches named in Par 1 were examined for a distance of about
1/4 mile from house. later on, and the same conditions found to exist.

PROPERTY
OF
DAVIDSON ROBERTSON.
VISIT # 2.
AUGUST 30th-21.

On August 30th in company with Capt Fisher and Drs. Hamilton, Dobson
and Sanders we visited the property of Davidson Robertson. We found
the exact conditions existing as was reported on my first visit. We
examined an outhouse for mosquitoes, but were unable to catch any, all
though there were several in the house.

We found a small pool of water standing near the well in yard which
contained a great many CULEX. Also found a rain barrel in rear of
house full of culex.

Robertson stated that he had taken no precautions against mosquitoes,
and did not even think it necessary to have his house screened.

PROPERTY
OF
DAN MALONEY.
SEPTEMBER 14th-21.

On Wednesday September 14th-21, Dr. Carter and myself examined the
property of Dan Maloney. This property is located about 1/2 mile from
the backwaters of Dutchmans creek. We examined a creak or small branch
about 1/4 mile from the old Maloney house and found free breeding of
ANOPHELES. This stream seemed to have a good flow od water in places,
and pooled in others. Stream bontained a large amount of trash and
debris. Examined several pools near stream and found most of them
breeding profusly.

We examined several pools between the above mentioned stream and the
tenant houses and found all of them to be breeding profusly. These
pools were in a large willow bottom which showed indications of being
constantly wet. Most of these pools contained very little water at
time of examination, but were ideal breeding places for ANOPHELES.
We termed this area as BREEDING PROFUSLY.

PROPERTY
OF
MAJOR BUSH.
SEPTEMBER 14th-21.

On Wednesday September 14th-21, Dr. Carter and myself examined the
Major Bush property. We examined the spring and spring branch which
is about 200 yards from the house occupied by Major Bush. We found
no breeding in spring, but found spring branch breeding freely. The
branch was grown up in weeds and grass and was an ideal breeding
place for ANOPHELES.

We next examined the creek which flowed about tewnty feet from spring
and into which the spring branch flowed. This stream was standing in
pools, held by rockey ledges and contained an abundance of ANOPHELES.
No gambusia were found in any of these pools.

Samples secured from several of the pools, and the soring branch hatched
out ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS.

As far as I am able to tell, I cannot see where the backwaters of the
main pond can possibly affect this stream at this point. Stream shows
no indications of being affected by backwaters.

PROPERTY
OF
DAN JONES.
SEPTEMBER 12th-21.

On September 12th 1921, Drs Carter, McKaskill and myself examined
the property of Dan Jones. We examined the spring and spring
branch about 200 yards from house on main road near the sawmill.
We found frofuse breeding of ANOPHELES in the spring and the
spring branch. There were several pools of water along edges of
spring branch that were breeding profusly.

We next examined the saw mill branch which is a part of the spring
branch. This branch was breeding profusly. Several pools along
edges of this branch were also breeding profusly.

We secured several specimens from the above areas, all of which
hatched out ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS.

I have never seen so small an area breeding more profusly than the
above.

PROPERTY
OF
DAN JONES.
SEPTEMBER 13th-21.

On September 13th-21, Drs. Carter, McKaskill and myself examined the
property of Dan Jones near Beaver Creek. We examined an unoccupied
house on a small knoll surrounded by water. We found no mosquitoes
in house or barn. This house evidently has been unoccupied for some
time. We examined the pond or backwaters and found no breeding. There
was no water supply on this property, the spring evidently having
been covered bu the backwater from the pond. The banks of pond
were fairly clean. Pond had good wave action on all sides of this
property. Pond contained a great many gambusia or top feeding minnows.
HILTON PROPERTY.
SEPTEMBER 13th-21.

On September 13th-21, Drs. Carter, McKaskill and myself examined the
property of Mr. Hilton. We examined Beaver Creek at a point about
1/2 mile from the Hilton house. We found free breeding in the creek
and profuse breeding in several pools standing near creek. The area
of creek at this point is grown up in trees and bushes and shows no
signs of cultivation. The bottoms along this creek are very marshy,
and seem to be ideal breeding places for ANOPHELES.

We took several specimens from different parts of creek, and several
pools which hatched out ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS.

We examined the spring and spring branch about 150 yards from the
Hilton house. We found free breeding in the spring branch, but no
breeding in spring. The spring branch had been recently cleaned out
and was probably breeding profusly prior to that time. The area of
the spring and spring branch is extremely marshy and an ideal breeding
place for ANOPHELES.

We took several specimens from spring branch which hatched out
ANOPHELES PUNCTIPENNIS.
BEAVER CREEK.
SEPTEMBER 13th-21.

On September 13th-21, Drs Carter, McKaskill and myself examined the
area around and above the mouth of Beaver Creek, just below the
Hilton Place. We found no breeding at the mouth. We found a few
half grown larvae in the deadwater of creek. We examined the creek
for about 3/4 mile from the mouth, and in several places found
free breeding.

We found profuse breeding in several side pools of water. This area
seems to be very marshy, and is grown up in swamp grass. It is an
ideal breeding place for ANOPHELES.

The specimens secured from above places hatched out ANOPHELES
PUNCTIPENNIS.
